title: 104_s2088
content: The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" allows for a credit for employer expenses for child care assistance under the new section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" introduces a credit for employer-provided child care expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit covers 50% of qualified child care expenditures, not exceeding $150,000 per year. Qualified expenses include property acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, or expansion for child care purposes. The term 'qualified child care expenditure' refers to amounts paid for property used as part of a qualified child care facility, eligible for depreciation deduction, and not part of the taxpayer's principal residence. The taxpayer can deduct operating costs for a qualified child care facility, including employee training, scholarship programs, and increased compensation for employees with higher child care training levels. The taxpayer can deduct operating costs for a qualified child care facility, including employee training, scholarship programs, and increased compensation for employees with higher child care training levels. This can be done under a contract with a qualified child care facility to provide dependent care services or resource and referral services to employees. The taxpayer can deduct operating costs for a qualified child care facility under a contract to provide dependent care resource and referral services to employees. A qualified child care facility is a facility that primarily provides dependent care assistance and meets all state or local regulations. A qualified child care facility must meet state or local regulations, including licensing requirements. The facility cannot be the operator's principal residence. A qualified child care facility must meet state or local regulations, including licensing requirements. Enrollment must be open to employees of the taxpayer, and the facility cannot be the principal trade or business of the taxpayer unless at least 30 percent of the enrollees are dependents of employees. The qualified child care facility must meet state or local regulations, including licensing requirements. Enrollment must be open to employees of the taxpayer, with at least 30 percent of enrollees being dependents. The facility cannot be the principal trade or business of the taxpayer and must not discriminate in favor of highly compensated employees. Taxpayers who are highly compensated employees may face a recapture event for a qualified child care facility, leading to an increase in their tax under this chapter. The recapture amount is determined by the applicable percentage and the decrease in credits allowed under section 38 for prior taxable years. The recapture amount for highly compensated employees at a qualified child care facility is calculated based on the applicable recapture percentage and the decrease in credits allowed under section 38 for prior taxable years. The applicable recapture percentage is determined from a specific table. The recapture amount for highly compensated employees at a qualified child care facility is calculated based on a specific table with decreasing percentages over the years. The recapture amount for highly compensated employees at a qualified child care facility decreases over the years, starting at 70% in Year 5 and reaching 0% in Years 11 and thereafter. The recapture event for a qualified child care facility includes the cessation of operation or change in ownership. The recapture event for a qualified child care facility involves the cessation of operation or change in ownership, where the taxpayer's interest is disposed of, and the new owner may assume recapture liability. The person acquiring an interest in a facility can agree in writing to assume recapture liability from the person disposing of the interest. This makes the acquiring person the taxpayer for recapture assessment purposes. The acquiring person can assume recapture liability from the disposing person, making them the taxpayer for recapture assessment purposes. The tax for the taxable year will only be increased for credits used to reduce tax liability. The tax for the taxable year will only be increased for credits used to reduce tax liability, with adjustments to carryforwards and carrybacks if credits are not used. No tax credits can be used to offset the increase in tax under this subsection. The increase in tax does not apply if a qualified child care facility ceases operation due to a casualty loss that is restored by reconstruction or replacement. The tax increase does not apply if a qualified child care facility stops operating due to a casualty loss that is restored by reconstruction or replacement within a reasonable period. Aggregation rules apply to all persons treated as a single employer. Under subsections (a) and (b) of section 52, a single employer is treated as a single taxpayer. Pass-thru rules apply to estates and trusts, similar to subsection (d) of section 52. In partnerships, the credit is allocated among partners as per regulations. No double benefit is allowed, with a reduction in basis for determining the credit under this subtitle. The credit in partnerships is allocated among partners based on regulations. No double benefit is allowed, with a reduction in basis for determining the credit under this subtitle. The basis of property is reduced by the determined credit amount. If a recapture amount is determined in a taxable year, the basis of the property is increased by that recapture amount. The section discusses the recapture amount and its impact on the basis of property. It also states that no other deductions or credits are allowed with respect to the credit determined under this section. The section is terminated for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. The section prohibits additional deductions or credits related to the determined credit amount. It is terminated for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Amendments are made to Section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The employer-provided child care credit under section 45D is added as a new paragraph. Amendments are made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The employer-provided child care credit under section 45D applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1996.
